structured_info.title_cn: 联网和自动驾驶车辆专用车道的全网安全影响
structured_info.title_en: Network-wide safety impacts of dedicated lanes for connected and autonomous vehicles
structured_info.abstract: Cooperative, Connected and Automated Mobility (CCAM) enabled by Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) has potential to change future transport systems. The findings from previous studies suggest that these technologies will improve traffic flow, reduce travel time and delays. Furthermore, these CAVs will be safer compared to existing vehicles. As these vehicles may have the ability to travel at a higher speed and with shorter headways, it has been argued that infrastructure-based measures are required to optimise traffic flow and road user comfort. One of these measures is the use of a dedicated lane for CAVs on urban highways and arterials and constitutes the focus of this research. As the potential impact on safety is unclear, the present study aims to evaluate the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for CAVs. A calibrated and validated microsimulation model developed in AIMSUN was used to simulate and produce safety results. These results were analysed with the help of the Surrogate Safety Assessment Model (SSAM).
structured_info.methodology: A calibrated and validated microsimulation model developed in AIMSUN was used to simulate and produce safety results. These results were analysed with the help of the Surrogate Safety Assessment Model (SSAM). The model includes human-driven vehicles (HDVs), 1st generation and 2nd generation autonomous vehicles (AVs) with different sets of parameters leading to different movement behaviour.
structured_info.conclusion: The simulation results revealed that with dedicated lane, the combination of 40-40-20 (i.e., 40% human-driven, 40% 1st generation AVs, 20% 2nd generation AVs) could be the optimum MPR for CAVs to achieve the best safety benefits. The findings in this study provide useful insight into the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for CAVs and could be used to develop a policy support tool for local authorities and practitioners.

analysis.Overview: This paper evaluates the safety impacts of dedicated lanes for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) using a microsimulation model. The study focuses on how dedicated lanes affect traffic conflicts and crash rates under varying market penetration rates (MPRs) of CAVs.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the transition phase where human-driven vehicles (HDVs) and CAVs will coexist on roads, posing challenges for traffic flow and safety.
The study aims to understand the safety implications of dedicated lanes for CAVs, which are proposed to optimize traffic flow and reduce interactions between HDVs and CAVs.
The authors highlight the lack of real-world data on CAV operations, necessitating simulation-based approaches to assess safety impacts.
The research is significant for urban planning and policy-making, providing insights into the safe integration of CAVs into existing transport systems.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering and road safety disciplines, particularly in the context of emerging autonomous vehicle technologies.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include dedicated lanes for CAVs, traffic microsimulation, and surrogate safety measures like Time to Collision (TTC).
The logical relationship involves simulating mixed traffic scenarios to evaluate how dedicated lanes affect safety metrics.
Key assumptions include the behavior parameters of 1st and 2nd generation CAVs, and the exclusion of pedestrian and cyclist interactions in the model.
The paper contributes a novel probabilistic method to estimate crash rates from traffic conflicts, advancing the field of traffic safety assessment.
Methodology: The study uses AIMSUN Next for microsimulation and SSAM for conflict analysis, with TTC thresholds tailored for HDVs and CAVs.
The methodology is novel in its application of a probabilistic approach to convert conflicts to crashes, though it acknowledges limitations in simulating real-world complexities.
Data sources include a calibrated Manchester road network model, with traffic counts and journey times used for validation.
Experimental design involves multiple replications with random seeds to account for stochastic traffic behavior, using rigorous evaluation metrics like conflicts per vehicle-kilometer.
The research follows a simulation-based paradigm, influenced by traffic engineering theories, which shapes its focus on quantitative safety metrics.
Results: Key results show a 53-58% reduction in traffic conflicts at high CAV MPRs with dedicated lanes, and up to a 48% reduction in estimated crashes.
The results are significant for policy support, though their reliability is constrained by simulation limitations and the exclusion of certain real-world factors.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The authors argue that dedicated lanes can enhance safety by reducing HDV-CAV interactions, supported by simulation results showing conflict reductions at optimal MPRs.
Logical steps include scenario testing, conflict analysis, and crash estimation, with strengths in comprehensive scenario coverage and weaknesses in real-world data absence.
Potential rebuttals, such as the underutilization of dedicated lanes at low MPRs, are addressed by recommending optimal MPR ranges.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include the innovative use of microsimulation and probabilistic crash estimation, providing actionable insights for policymakers.
Limitations involve the model's inability to simulate crashes directly and the exclusion of non-vehicle road users.
The theoretical paradigm constrains conclusions by focusing on quantifiable metrics, potentially overlooking qualitative safety aspects.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within the discourse on CAV integration, using technical terminology and citations to established safety models to build authority.
Rhetorical strategies include emphasizing the novelty of the probabilistic method and the practical implications for urban planning.
Conclusions_and_Implications: The study concludes that dedicated lanes for CAVs can significantly improve safety at optimal MPRs, recommending the 40-40-20 fleet composition for best results.
Future research should address model limitations, include non-vehicle road users, and validate findings with real-world data as CAV technologies mature.
